awd_titl_txt: RAPID/Collaborative Research: Field Study of Volunteer Convergence in Post-Disaster Relief
awd_abstract_narration:
The emergency response to Hurricane Harvey involved not only traditional relief agencies but many ordinary citizens and small groups who felt compelled to assist the many residents who found themselves stranded in the face of rising flood waters.  Many volunteers brought personal watercraft and organized rescue missions along flooded streets and bayous.  Other groups, such as religious organizations, small businesses, and service organizations, opened their doors as informal shelters, with the congregations or organization members serving as volunteers and providing food and shelter for displaced individuals. These spontaneous volunteers represent a valuable source of labor but present significant logistical challenges for central response planners.  The spontaneous volunteer labor force is largely unpredictable, may enter and leave at will, and possess a variety of useful skills.  Moreover, while individuals may have good intentions in volunteering, they are largely untrained in emergency response and may present dangers to themselves and to others.  This RAPID award will provide a  better understanding of the dynamics of spontaneous volunteer response and should improve the ability of response planners to effectively incorporate citizen volunteers in disaster relief efforts.  A graduate student and undergraduate students will be involved in this effort and will be provided valuable experience by working on this research project.   

This award will provide support for data collection efforts in Houston, Texas in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey with several research objectives in mind: (1) to understand the organizational dynamics associated with volunteer intake and assignment; (2) to create and validate analytical models for volunteer intake and service length; (3) to understand the barriers to successful incorporation of spontaneous volunteers into the emergency response to disasters.  The PIs will collect data from a number of groups involved in the relief effort, including religious organizations, local businesses, ad-hoc groups, and traditional relief agencies.  The PIs will observe activities in active relief operations, interview relief staff and volunteers, and collect and analyze volunteer logs and disaster management systems.  These data will provide valuable input for predictive models for volunteer convergence.

por.por_cntn:
Volunteer convergence refers to the influx of individuals and groups of people looking for ways to contribute to relief efforts following major disasters. While the convergence of spontaneous volunteers into affected areas benefits relief efforts in many ways, their presence can inhibit organized relief operations if these spontaneous volunteers are not managed properly. Furthermore, the logistics of volunteer convergence present unique opportunities for contributions from the field of Operations Research and the Management Sciences (OR/MS), namely workforce planning and scheduling with a labor force who randomly arrive and abandon the relief efforts.

 

This study examined the post disaster volunteer management efforts during the relief efforts following Hurricane Harvey in Houston Texas. The work was a field study in which the primary goal was to document the logistical issues surrounding the management of spontaneous volunteers, paying particular attention to the characteristics of volunteer convergence that could benefit from OR/MS methods. By working closely with a Houston based nongovernment organization (NGO) who was actively involved with Hurricane Harvey relief efforts and who depended heavily on volunteer labor, we developed diagrams that showed the process in which spontaneous volunteers were integrated into relief operations from a logistical standpoint. Our findings provided new insights into the logistics of volunteer convergence that differ from the results of previous studies. In particular, we found that virtual Volunteer Reception Centers (VRCs) for organizing and deploying spontaneous volunteers were prevalent during the Hurricane Harvey response compared to earlier disaster events that featured physical VRCs for these purposes.

 

The intellectual merit of this project focused on contributions to the OR/MS field. Specifically, the framework we developed that describes the logistics of volunteer convergence based on our field work represents unique modeling opportunities and potentially new solution approaches. We also gathered quantitative data related to spontaneous volunteers that can be used to construct predictive models of volunteer arrivals, departures, and the number of volunteers to expect. Similarly, we obtained donation data that can be used to predict donation quantities, and demand data that can be used to predict needs.

 

The broader impacts of this project represents a benefit to society in the sense that effective management of spontaneous volunteers directly impacts how long disaster survivors have to wait to obtain basic necessities. Furthermore, this project has implications that can help relieve some of the anxiety that emergency managers face concerning the management of spontaneous volunteers, which will enable them to better serve disaster survivors. This project also employed individuals historically underrepresented in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines, including two women and one African American, both of whom were undergraduate students.
